I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is finalizing a regional cooperation strategy (RCS)1 
for  archipelagic  Southeast  Asia  (aSEA). 2  This  RCS  includes  several  key  subregional 
cooperation  initiatives  that  ADB  has  been  supporting,  including  the  Brunei  Darussalam-
Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area3 (BIMP-EAGA) and the Indonesia-
Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT).4 Both programs focus on connecting outlying 
regions of neighboring countries, providing the opportunity to develop growth centers away from 
their respective capitals. These outlying regions are characterized by high levels of poverty 
relative  to  national  averages  and  are  scattered  over  many  islands,  making  transport  and 
communications relatively expensive.  
 
2.  In 2005, the leaders of BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT requested ADB to increase its support 
for both programs, which had shown uneven progress. In response, ADB approved regional 
technical assistance (RETA)5 to support the development and implementation of road maps to 
enhance the capacity and effectiveness of both subregional programs. The proposed RETA will 
permit ADB to maintain its support for implementing these road maps, focusing on (i) effective 
institutional and coordinating mechanisms, (ii) capacity to respond to emerging issues on a 
subregional level, (iii) leveraging of public resources by private investment, and (iv) promoting 
information sharing and dissemination, all within a results-focused framework. The proposed 
RETA will also support new subregional activities identified in the aSEA RCS, and is consistent 
with  ADB's  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Strategy  (2006–2010)  and  the  current 
memorandum  of  understanding  with  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN) 
Secretariat. The design and monitoring framework for this RETA is in Appendix 1.6 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The aSEA region contains both middle- and high-income countries, with large income 
disparities between and within them. It generally enjoyed high growth rates until the 1997 Asian 
financial crisis; since then, its countries’ economies have showed more moderate growth, with 
GDP growth averaging 5.3% from 2003 to 2006.7 Poverty indicators have improved, although 
the  record  in  non-income  Millennium  Development  Goals  is  more  mixed,  as  regional  and  
intra-country disparities are pronounced. aSEA countries all face issues of how to reinvigorate 
and ensure sustainable and inclusive growth, and encouraging higher investment—especially 
by the private sector—is a challenge. The countries have long stressed the importance of

regional cooperation, as they helped to establish ASEAN.8 In addition, with the exception of 
Singapore, aSEA countries have been cooperating in BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT. 
 
4.  A defining characteristic of the region is its unique geography, which stretches 5,200 
kilometers from east to west and 3,400 kilometers from north to south. Its archipelagic nature 
emphasizes particular challenges to reducing poverty. The thousands of scattered islands are 
thinly populated, with local businesses facing high—and often uncertain—real transport and 
communication costs as well as susceptibility to natural disasters. Urgent social problems, 
including  trafficking  in  persons  and  HIV/AIDS,  as  well  as  the  region’s  deteriorating 
environmental, marine, and terrestrial resource base, have had disproportionate impacts on its 
poor.  
 
5.  The aSEA region is a true “neighborhood”9 with many shared problems, and steps 
toward working together to address them have occurred under the subregional programs. IMT-
GT, formed in 1993, has a total population of over 65 million, while BIMP-EAGA, which was 
formally launched in 1994 as a key strategy of participating governments to promote the social 
and economic development of their less-developed and more remote territories, has around 58 
million people. Both initiatives are focused on promoting trade, investment, and tourism with an 
emphasis on private sector-led growth, and have contributed to improved air and sea links, 
lowered trade barriers, and promotion of cross-border investment. BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT 
were  created  when  the  region’s  economies  were  surging  and  leaders  sought  to  extend 
economic growth to more isolated regions through greater cooperation. However, the 1997 
Asian financial crisis disrupted early plans and slowed progress in both initiatives. 
 
6.  Regional  cooperation  in  BIMP-EAGA  and  IMT-GT  is  not  only  subregional  but  also 
subnational, linking parts of relatively large, middle-income countries often separated by vast 
bodies of water. The islands comprising BIMP-EAGA are closer to one another than to their 
respective capitals, implying a potential for trade among themselves or directly with the rest of 
the world.  
 
7.  At separate leaders' summits, held alongside the 11th ASEAN Summit in Kuala Lumpur 
in  December  2005,  regional  leaders  reaffirmed  their  commitment  to  the  revitalization  of  
BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT. ADB was requested to continue its critical role in further developing 
the institutional capacity for both initiatives, including by giving priority to developing a road map 
for IMT-GT10 and an approach for quantifying achievements and activities. It is also clear that 
local government units (LGUs) must be more involved in subregional cooperation activities,  and 
their capacity must be strengthened. In addition, finding new ways to measure the impact of 
(sub-) regional programs as a whole is crucial. 
 
8.  At the 4th BIMP-EAGA Summit and the 3rd IMT-GT Summit, both held in Singapore on 
19  November  2007,11 regional  leaders  unanimously  commended  ADB  for  supporting  both 
initiatives and requested that ADB continue and increase such support. Specifically for BIMP-
EAGA,  the  leaders  requested  increased  support  for  private  sector  development,  capacity

building of subregional institutions, and resource mobilization for the implementation of the 
BIMP-EAGA road map.12 For IMT-GT, the leaders requested ADB support for the development 
of economic corridors and noted that in-depth studies were needed, including analysis of the 
trade and investment climate as well as more detailed transport sector assessments. IMT-GT 
leaders also requested ADB assistance to help mobilize financial and technical resources for 
implementing prioritized projects identified in the IMT-GT road map. 
 
9.  The draft RCS provides a strategic focus for ADB’s support for regional cooperation 
within aSEA, and concentrates on two principal development constraints in which regional 
cooperation  and  integration  can  have  a  positive  impact:  lagging  competitiveness 13 and 
environmental degradation. The initial challenge is to facilitate a process for aSEA countries to 
collaborate in addressing these constraints, without creating undue institutional structures and 
using existing ones as much as possible. Issues also include the availability of relevant baseline 
information, the establishment of an effective results-based monitoring and evaluation (RBME) 
framework,  and  continued  capacity  building  on  a  subregional  basis.  An  RBME  is  being 
developed for BIMP-EAGA, but this must be expanded to cover all of aSEA and to address the 
region’s  development  constraints.  The  BIMP-EAGA  Facilitation  Center  in  Kota  Kinabalu, 
Malaysia and the new Center for IMT-GT Subregional Cooperation14 in Selangor, Malaysia also 
require capacity-building support. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the RETA will be to strengthen regional cooperation in development 
activities within aSEA. The outcome of the RETA will be to accelerate the implementation of 
road maps for BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT through region-wide development and to provide for 
RBME.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  Management  for  Development  Results.  The  RETA  will  establish  an  appropriate 
baseline of monitorable indicators for regional cooperation in aSEA, including indicators specific 
to BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT, as well as for the whole region. This will supplement work begun 
under RETA 6352, which provided for the development of an RBME system for BIMP-EAGA. 
The need for a project development process (PDP) became apparent during implementation, 
and a draft PDP has been prepared. The proposed RETA will complete this process, and assist 
in developing a similar system for IMT-GT. This will also include an investment and trade survey.  
 
12.  Capacity  Building  for  Enhanced  Effectiveness.  The  RETA  will  support  capacity-
building activities for cooperation among governments, working groups, planning groups, and 
secretariats associated with aSEA. A rapid assessment of BIMP-EAGA’s institutional structures 
and mechanisms has been completed and will be followed by a detailed assessment under the 
midterm review of the road map.15 A capacity-building strategy and framework for BIMP-EAGA 
is under preparation and expected to be finalized by mid-2008. The RETA will support the 
implementation  of  that  strategy  during  its  first  year.  The  coordination  and  implementation

capacity of the BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Center will be strengthened through a training needs 
assessment and subsequent training for staff. The Center for IMT-GT Subregional Cooperation 
is being established, and the RETA will provide support to ensure its professional management, 
review  organizational  and  coordination  mechanisms  and  structures,  and  provide  relevant 
training programs. All capacity building training will be conducted through regional activities that 
will benefit all participating countries. 
 
13.  aSEA’s  geographic  structure  dictates  that  LGUs  are  vital  to  promoting  subregional 
cooperation, but their current capacity in this role is limited. Under IMT-GT, the RETA will 
undertake a capacity needs assessment of LGUs, and LGU capacity-building activities will be 
implemented  in  both  BIMP-EAGA  and  IMT-GT  through  regional  workshops.  In  IMT-GT, 
associated  working  groups  will  be  supported  through  prioritization  and  implementation  of 
projects, studies, and working group strategies.  
 
14.  Other  Subregional  Cooperation.  Earlier  reviews  have  identified  potential  for 
subregional  cooperation  activities  between  Papua,  Indonesia  and  Papua  New  Guinea  and 
between West Timor, Indonesia and Timor Leste. ADB's Pacific Department and Southeast Asia 
Department will study potential areas for cross-border activities and develop relevant projects 
with the guidance of the Pacific regional strategy and its operations business plan,16 as well as 
the RCS. A third area for subregional cooperation is between Riau Islands, Indonesia and 
Singapore. In this case, it is expected that ADB's support will complement assistance provided 
by Singapore and focus on agri-business development, and possibly tourism and fisheries.  
 
15.  Responsive  and  Informed  Policy  Dialogue.  Regional  cooperation  in  aSEA  is 
developing in a dynamic context, characterized by changes in the global and regional economic, 
financial, and trading environments; increased prominence of climate change, energy efficiency, 
and environmental degradation; and evolving global and regional dimensions of security, crime, 
trafficking, public health, and other social issues. The RETA provides for the engagement of 
experts who will prepare prompt, policy-oriented advice on emergent issues requiring regional 
responses. Such requests for assistance can come from any stakeholder under the usual  
BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT processes or from two or more governments in aSEA. 
 
16.  Coordination. It is widely recognized by the aSEA governments that the private sector 
must play a key role in driving economic growth and investing in development throughout the 
region.  Public-private  partnerships  in  infrastructure  provision  are  necessary  given  many 
countries’ fiscal constraints and also ensure that infrastructure is efficiently operated. Given the 
large income disparities between the countries, there are also opportunities for cross-border 
investments  by  governments.  The  RETA  will  facilitate  coordination  among  and  between 
governments and between governments and the private sector through seminars, workshops, 
and the engagement of experts in specific areas as required. The RETA will also continue to 
provide coordination support with other donor agencies active in the region. 
 
17.  Consultation and Information. The aSEA neighborhood shares common issues that 
require  common  approaches.  For  such  regional  cooperation  to  be  effective,  various 
stakeholders in the region must work together to share information and draw lessons from these 
shared  problems  and  solutions,  and  the  RETA  will  continue  to  support  this  process.  
BIMP-EAGA  developed  a  communications  strategy  with  ADB  support,  and  the  RETA  will 
provide for its implementation. Communication needs for aSEA and IMT-GT will be evaluated,

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $3.8 million, which will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s technical assistance funding program. The cost estimates and budget are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB’s  Country  Coordination  and  Regional  Cooperation  Division,  Southeast  Asia 
Regional Department will be the Executing Agency (EA), responsible for implementing and 
monitoring the RETA. The EA will (i) provide and/or mobilize financial resources for regional 
projects,  programs,  and  technical  assistance;  (ii)  create,  consolidate,  and  disseminate 
knowledge and information on aSEA; (iii) help countries and (sub-) regional bodies build their 
institutional capacity to manage regional cooperation; and (iv) act as facilitator, catalyst, and 
coordinator  of  regional  cooperation.  The  EA's  actual  role  will  vary  in  each  subregional 
neighborhood, depending on issues to be addressed. Implementation will be conducted in close 
consultation  with  the  relevant  ADB  resident  missions,  the  BIMP-EAGA  Facilitation  Center, 
Center for IMT-GT Subregional Cooperation, and the ASEAN Secretariat.  
 
20.  The RETA will finance about 260 person-months of consultant services, 99 international 
and 161 national. Consultants will also be engaged for short-term studies. Consultants will be 
hired as individuals and engaged according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time). Consultants’ outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. ADB 
will be actively involved in the implementation of the RETA, including workshop organization 
and associated staffing. The RETA will be implemented over a period of about 24 months, from 
March 2008 to February 2010. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
21.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $3,800,000 on a grant basis for Institutional Development for 
Enhanced Subregional Cooperation in the aSEA Region.

months)

(iv)  manage the exchange of relevant information between this RETA and 
others.
